sections.title: King and Pawn Endgames
sections.content:
**The Opposition**: When kings face each other with one square between, the player who doesn't move has the opposition. This is crucial for promoting pawns.

**Key Square**: The square a pawn needs to reach to guarantee promotion. Understanding key squares helps you know when a pawn is winning.

**Triangulation**: A technique to lose a tempo and force zugzwang. The king moves in a triangle to return to the same position but on the opponent's turn.

**Outside Passed Pawn**: A passed pawn far from the main action. Often decisive because it forces the enemy king away.

**Pawn Races**: When both sides have passed pawns, calculate who promotes first. Count moves carefully!

sections.title: Rook and Pawn Endgames
sections.content:
**Lucena Position**: A winning technique when you have a rook and pawn vs. rook. The key is cutting off the enemy king and promoting the pawn.

**Philidor Position**: A drawing technique when defending rook and pawn vs. rook. The defending rook stays on the 6th rank, preventing the pawn from advancing.

**Back Rank Weakness**: In rook endgames, weak back ranks are deadly. Always be aware of back rank checkmates.

**Active Rook**: An active rook (behind passed pawns, on open files) is much stronger than a passive rook.

**Rook vs. Pawns**: A rook can often stop multiple pawns, but calculation is essential.

sections.title: Queen Endgames
sections.content:
**Queen vs. Pawn**: Usually winning for the queen, but some positions are drawn (pawn on 7th rank with king support).

**Queen and Pawn vs. Queen**: Usually winning, but requires precise technique. The key is advancing the pawn while keeping the king safe.

**Perpetual Check**: In queen endgames, perpetual check is a common drawing resource. Look for it when behind.

**Queen Activity**: The queen is most powerful when active. Centralize it and use it to attack multiple targets.

sections.title: Minor Piece Endgames
sections.content:
**Bishop vs. Knight**: Usually equal, but bishops are better in open positions, knights in closed positions.

**Opposite-Colored Bishops**: Often drawn even with extra pawns. The defending bishop can control squares the attacking bishop cannot.

**Bishop and Pawn vs. Bishop**: Usually winning if the pawn can advance, but some positions are drawn.

**Knight Endgames**: Knights are tricky. They can't lose a tempo, so zugzwang is common. Calculation is essential.

sections.title: Zugzwang
sections.content:
**Definition**: A position where any move makes your position worse. You're forced to move, but every move is bad.

**Common in Endgames**: Zugzwang is most common in endgames, especially king and pawn endgames.

**Creating Zugzwang**: Force your opponent into zugzwang by improving your position until they have no good moves.

**Triangulation**: A technique to create zugzwang by losing a tempo.

**Recognition**: Learn to recognize zugzwang positions. They often decide endgames.

sections.title: General Endgame Principles
sections.content:
**King Activity**: In the endgame, the king is a powerful piece. Centralize it and use it actively.

**Pawn Promotion**: The goal of most endgames. Create passed pawns and support them.

**Piece Activity**: Active pieces are crucial. Passive pieces are often useless.

**Simplification**: When ahead, simplify. When behind, complicate.

**Calculation**: Endgames require precise calculation. Count moves carefully.

**Technique**: Learn standard endgame techniques (Lucena, Philidor, etc.). They occur frequently.

**Patience**: Endgames often require patience. Don't rush - calculate carefully.
